742
Observations upon the Anatomy and 
Physiology of Salpa & Pyrosoma 
together with remarks upon Doliolum and Appendicularia.
By Thomas Henry Huxley -
communicated by Edward Forbes FRS
Received Feby 26. Read -
The Salpae, those strange gelatinous animals,
through masses of which the voyager in the 
great ocean sometimes sails day after day -
have been the subject of great controversy 
since the time of the publication of the celebrated 
work of Chamisso “De animalibus quibusdam 
e classe Vermium Linnaeana “ -
In this work were set forth, for the first 
time the <s>strange <\s> singular phenomena presented by 
the reproductive Inocenes of these animals:-
phenomena so strange, and so utterly unlike 
anything then known to occur in the whole 
province of Zoology, that Chamisso’s admirably 
clear and faithful account, was received 
with almost as much distrust as if he had 
announced the existence of a veritable Peter Schleinkl.
In later days an opposite fate has fallen upon 
the <s>theory <\s> statements in question. They have been made the 
keystone of a <s>new <\s> revived* theory, and the phenomena 
presented by the Salpae have been cited as ‘plainly 
instances ‘ of a law governing the vast majority 
of the lower Invertebrata - the law of the “Alternation 
of Generations “
* not new. see 5.
